abstract.p: Excerpts from previously published reviews of restaurants near United Nations headquarters in Manhattan (Good Eating column) (M)

block.p: AVRA * [Rating: One Star] (212) 759-8550; 141 East 48th Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues; $$$; smoking section; all major credit cards.

Avra offers a fish tour just after the aperitifs, which makes for a highly entertaining and educational five minutes. The seafood counter at this Greek restaurant is an eye-pleasing panorama, offering about a dozen fish listed on the menu. Appetizers include carp roe mousse with fresh lemon juice and red onion; spicy feta cheese spread with sauteed sweet red pepper and olive oil; and oven-baked giant Greek lima beans. Entrees include Atlantic salmon wrapped in grape leaves with baked orzo; souvlaki of grilled swordfish with tomato and peppers; and oven-baked Chilean sea bass with Vidalia onions, tomato and herbs. Also on the menu is lamb loin chops with lemon Avra potatoes and okra and grilled dry aged sirloin steak with feta-stuffed tomato and charred onions. (Review: 4/19/00)
AVRA * [Rating: One Star] (212) 759-8550; 141 East 48th Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues; $$$; smoking section; all major credit cards.

Avra offers a fish tour just after the aperitifs, which makes for a highly entertaining and educational five minutes. The seafood counter at this Greek restaurant is an eye-pleasing panorama, offering about a dozen fish listed on the menu. Appetizers include carp roe mousse with fresh lemon juice and red onion; spicy feta cheese spread with sauteed sweet red pepper and olive oil; and oven-baked giant Greek lima beans. Entrees include Atlantic salmon wrapped in grape leaves with baked orzo; souvlaki of grilled swordfish with tomato and peppers; and oven-baked Chilean sea bass with Vidalia onions, tomato and herbs. Also on the menu is lamb loin chops with lemon Avra potatoes and okra and grilled dry aged sirloin steak with feta-stuffed tomato and charred onions. (Review: 4/19/00)
DIWAN GRILL +++ (212) 593-5425; 148 East 48th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues; $$; smoking at the bar; all major credit cards.

This sedate midtown Indian restaurant is easy to overlook, but it is worth seeking out. The menu is standard New York Indian, heavy on the tandoor, but almost everything is well prepared and lively. Appetizers include tandoor-roasted shrimp; katori chat, which is phyllo cup potatoes, tomatoes, tamarind and mint sauce; and a mixed grill of chicken malai kebab, lambseekh kebab, shrimp and tandoor chicken. Entrees include skewered minced lamb kebabs, flavored with mild cheese; shrimp, lamb or chicken prepared in a vindaloo sauce, which is a very hot coconut and red pepper curry sauce; lamb korma, with cashews and saffron flavored sauce; and chicken tikka masala. (New York Today: April 1998)
HATSUHANA RESTAURANT ** [Rating: Two stars] (212) 355-3345; 17 East 48th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues; $$$; no smoking; all major credit cards.

Hatsuhana is a comfortable and welcoming restaurant where you can depend on being served high-quality sushi whether you speak Japanese or not. Appetizers include white fish, shimeji mushrooms, clams and black olives flame broiled in olive oil; lobster wrapped in corn with a creamy lobster sauce; and slices of duck with scallions. Entrees include grilled Norwegian salmon with teriyaki sauce and vegetables; assortment of shrimp and vegetables fried in soybean oil; and a full-course dinner with oshitashi, sashimi, lobster-corn, tempura and sushi. (Review: 8/30/96)
MARICHU +++ (212) 370-1866; 342 East 46th Street, between First and Second Avenues; $$$; smoking permitted; all major credit cards; www.marichu.com.

Marichu serves unusual Basque dishes in a location near the United Nations, frequently drawing a crowd of diplomats. Appetizers include white asparagus on piquillo peppers with a scallion and olive vinaigrette; endives with a Cabrales cheese and yogurt sauce surrounded by fresh orange wedges; and sizzling garlic shrimps. Main courses include seafood paella; sauteed monkfish in garlic sauce with clams and shrimp; cannelloni of spinach and shrimp with tomato sauce; and grilled filet mignon with red roasted peppers and scalloped potatoes. (New York Today: April 1998)
Summaries taken from reviews use the star ratings. Others are taken from the $25 and Under column (+) and articles (++), and capsule revies from New York Today: www.nytoday.com (+++).
**** -- Extraordinary *** -- Excellent ** -- Very Good * -- Good None Poor to Satisfactory
Price Range Based on the cost of a three-course dinner, per person, tax, tip and drinks not included.

Past Reviews -- Good Eating columns back to June 1998, along with reviews from The Times and capsule reviews by Times critics of additional restaurants not reviewed in the newspaper, are available on New York Today.
